Description: Foot and lower body sherd (mended from three fragments) of large Corinthian black-figured pottery lekane; slightly flaring ring foot; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of boar, facing to right (tail, legs and head missing); part of three incised rosettes with added red dot in the centre of two as filling ornament; exterior: black-figure animal frieze (only hooves of deer, to left, and paws of panther, to right, remaining) with incised blob and splinter rosettes as filling ornament; glazed area below handle zone; below, two bands and frieze of rays; inside and outside of foot glazed; glaze ring on underside.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Athens 931
Curator's comments: The sherd possibly belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1886, 0401.1043.a, 1886,0401.1043.b, 1886, 0401.994 and 1886, 0401.1009. 1886,0401.1054, which cannot be from the same piece as 1008 because of overlap, is another candidate for the tondo. C.W. Neeft (personal communication) considers that the lekane is the work of the Painter of Athens 931.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.7.1)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 92, no. A121)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 36)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.114) (Phase 1)
